We support Israels right to exist as a Jewish state with secure, defensible borders;
and we envision two democratic states Israel with Jerusalem as its capital and Palestine living in peace and security.
For that to happen, the Palestinian people must support leaders who reject terror,  embrace the institutions and ethos of democracy, and respect the rule of law.
We call on Arab governments throughout the region to help advance that goal.
Israel should not be expected to negotiate with entities pledged to her destruction.
We call on the new government in Egypt to fully uphold its peace treaty with Israel.
The U.S. seeks a comprehensive and lasting peace in the Middle East, negotiated between the parties themselves with the assistance of the U.S., without the imposition of an artificial timetable.

Essential to that process will be a just, fair, and realistic framework for dealing with the issues that can be settled on the basis of mutually agreed changes reflecting todays realities as well as tomorrows hopes.

We recognize the historic nature of the events of the past two yearsthe Arab Springthat have unleashed democratic movements leading to the overthrow of dictators who have been menaces to global security for decades.
In a season of upheaval, it is necessary to be prepared for anything.
That is true on the ground in the Middle East, and it will be equally true in the next Administration, particularly with a new President unbound by the failures of the past.
We welcome the aspirations of the Arab peoples and others for greater freedom, and we hope that greater libertyand with it, a greater chance for peacewill result from the recent turmoil.

Many governments in the region have given substantial assistance to the U.S. over the last decade because they understood that our struggle against terror is not an ethnic or religious fight, and that violent extremists are abusers of their faith, not its champions.
On the other hand, radical elements like Hamas and Hezbollah must be isolated because they do not meet the standards of peace and diplomacy of the international community.
We call for the restoration of Lebanons independence, which those groups have virtually destroyed.
We support the transition to a postAssad Syrian government that is representative of its people,
protects the rights of all minorities and religions,
respects the territorial integrity of its neighbors,
and contributes to peace and stability in the region.
We offer a continuing partnership with the people of Iraq, who have endured extremist terror to now have a chance to build their own security and democracy.
We urge special efforts to preserve and protect the ethnic and religious diversity of their nation.
Irans pursuit of nuclear weapons capability threatens America, Israel, and the world.
That threat has only become worse during the current Administration.
A continuation of its failed engagement policy with Iran will lead to nuclear cascade.
In solidarity with the international community, America must lead the effort to prevent Iran from building and possessing nuclear weapons capability.
We express our respect for the people of Iran, who seek peace
and aspire to freedom.
Their current regime is unworthy of them.
It exports terror and provided weapons that killed our troops in Iraq.

We affirm the unanimous resolution of the U.S. Senate calling for elections that are free, fair, and meet international standards and a representative and responsive democratic government that respects human rights, civil liberties, and the rule of law.
We urge the next Republican President to unequivocally assert his support for the Iranian people as they protest their despotic regime.
We must retain all options in dealing with a situation that gravely threatens our security, our interests, and the safety of our friends.
Une conomie innovante est une conomie verte.
Une conomie innovante patine l o sen va la rondelle.
Elle transforme les emplois de col bleu des vieilles industries en emplois de col vert au sein des nouvelles industries.
Elle mise sur la production  valeur ajoute et gnre les produits verts qui seront en demande sur les marchs de demain.
Une conomie innovante est une conomie efficace.
Elle dpend dune multitude de sources dnergie et de systmes non polluants.
Elle endigue le gaspillage.
Elle rutilise et recycle.
Grce  des systmes en circuit ferm, elle est considrablement plus efficace.
Cette efficacit confre une comptitivit et une prosprit accrues  lensemble de lconomie canadienne.
Une conomie innovante nest pas un engouement passager.
Ce sont de vraies gens, qui construisent de vraies choses, dont les vraies gens ont besoin.
Une conomie innovante fonctionne  la mesure de ses moyens.
La premire tape consiste  sortir de cette rcession sans pour autant avoir une dette et un dficit accablants.
Le Parti vert a un plan pour enrayer le dficit et rtablir lquilibre budgtaire.
Crer des milliers d'emplois grce  des investissements dans l'nergie renouvelable,

l'largissement du service ferroviaire voyageur et  la modernisation du transport ferroviaire de marchandises ainsi qu' la modernisation de milliers de btiments pour qu'ils rpondent  des normes leves d'efficacit nergtique .

Rformer, revoir et refondre nos accords commerciaux;
le commerce fait partie intgrante d'un avenir durable uniquement lorsqu'il est quitable pour tous.
Dynamiser le secteur agricole en accordant des subventions  ceux et celles qui souhaitent effectuer la transition  l'agriculture biologique;

Mettre un terme  la stratgie non viable qui consiste  gaspiller du bon argent pour renflouer de grandes socits  la drive et
subventionner le nuclaire et les combustibles fossiles.
Redresser les prix pour assurer la viabilit  long terme;
viter les dficits structuraux;
instaurer une politique de prix sur le carbone sans incidence sur les recettes afin de moderniser notre conomie;
btir une conomie verte  fabrique au Canada.
Les collectivits sont bien plus que de simples entits gographiques.
Les collectivits, ce sont des gens qui vivent ensemble, qui prennent soin les uns des autres et qui font des activits ensemble.
Les collectivits qui fonctionnent ne sont pas bties sans effort.

Nous devons pouvoir compter sur des systmes de transport qui nous amnent dun endroit  lautre rapidement, efficacement et en toute scurit, des services deau qui garantissent une eau propre et de qualit.

Il faut pouvoir y retrouver tous les biens communs que nous aimons : des aires de jeu, des pistes cyclables, des espaces verts, des jardins communautaires, des habitations dcentes, de bonnes coles pour nos enfants et un systme de soins de sant publique qui tient compte de tous les aspects de notre bien-tre.
Amliorer la qualit de vie en trouvant un quilibre entre le travail et le foyer.
Une vie plus humanise qui fait une place aux choses qui comptent vraiment.
Gagner sa vie ne devrait jamais empcher quelquun de profiter de sa vie.
Des collectivits dynamiques passent par la cration de possibilits pour les jeunes Canadiennes et les jeunes Canadiens.
Les jeunes btissent les collectivits, autant des collectivits physiques dans leur milieu de vie que des collectivits virtuelles sur Internet.
Les jeunes remplis dnergie font partie dun avenir vritablement vert.
Un nombre croissant de Canadiennes et de Canadiens vieillissants sont actifs et engags.
Ils ont beaucoup apport  notre pays et veulent continuer de participer  lavenir du pays.
Ils doivent tre en mesure de maintenir le style de vie quils dsirent, tout en conservant leur dignit et leur indpendance.
Rquilibrer le systme fiscal; permettre la rpartition des revenus entre tous les adultes d'une famille de manire  rduire le fardeau fiscal des couples et des familles.

Partager le fardeau; de plus en plus de gens travaillent de moins en moins d'heures; pour ceux qui le souhaitent, favoriser le tltravail ou le travail  la maison; partager les emplois; instaurer des horaires flexibles;
instaurer des programmes de garde d'enfants flexibles et accessibles  tous;
miser sur l'ducation des jeunes enfants;
augmenter le nombre de places de garde d'enfants sur les lieux de travail;
appuyer les parents qui choisissent de demeurer  la maison pour lever leurs enfants
et soutenir ceux qui doivent retourner sur le march du travail quand leurs enfants sont encore jeunes.
Offrir un financement stable et  long terme aux municipalits pour la rparation de leurs infrastructures vieillissantes;
btir pour l'avenir; crer davantage de commodits communes dont ont besoin toutes les collectivits pour les loisirs,
le transport,
les services d'eau,
les arts et la culture.
Faire en sorte d'assurer des pensions de retraite
et fournir des programmes axs sur la sant - physique et mentale - tout en assurant la dignit en mettant un terme  l'abus des ans et en respectant les testaments biologiques.
La dmocratie canadienne est en difficult.
Le pouvoir est de plus en plus centralis.
Les dputs individuels  votre voix au Parlement  semblent avoir perdu toute leur pertinence.
La priode des questions est le thtre quotidien de comportements quaucun parent ne tolrerait chez ses enfants.
Lheure est venue de rtablir une vraie dmocratie et de restituer le pouvoir aux Canadiennes et aux Canadiens.
Une dmocratie vritable signifie que chaque vote compte.
Au-del des votes, cela signifie lengagement et le dbat dans le respect dautrui.
Cela signifie travailler ensemble et concevoir une dmarche concerte et positive pour aller vers lavenir.
Comme Canadiennes et Canadiens, nous sommes fiers dtre reconnus mondialement pour notre nature civile et cooprative.
Nos instincts nous dictent gnrosit et compassion.
Soyons-en fiers.
Tandis que le Canada rduit le gaspillage au sein de son conomie et de son industrie, il devrait galement cesser de gaspiller des votes.
Adoptons un systme lectoral plus quitable, qui reprsente la volont profonde de llectorat.
Une dmocratie vritable passe par une citoyennet vritablement mondiale.
Par le pass, dautres nations de notre village mondial se sont tournes vers le Canada pour son leadership  maintien de la paix et rtablissement de la paix, dsarmement et durabilit de lenvironnement.
Le moment est venu pour le Canada de faire un nouvel effort et de jouer encore une fois le rle de chef de file quil sentte  renier depuis quelques annes.
Organiser des consultations nationales sur l'tat de notre dmocratie,
lutter contre la concentration antidmocratique du pouvoir au cabinet du premier ministre
et explorer les pistes de solution pour nous doter d'un systme lectoral plus reprsentatif;
examiner les risques du systme uninominal majoritaire  un tour et voter pour dterminer s'il doit ou non tre remplac;
envisager un mode de reprsentation proportionnelle.
Envisager de vraies solutions pour contrer la concentration accrue du contrle du journalisme canadien par des intrts capitalistes;
tout ce qui a t  nivel par le bas  doit dsormais tre  nivel par le haut.
La justice et l'galit sociales sont les pierres angulaires de la dmocratie.
La dmocratie canadienne fonctionne mieux lorsque les droits de la personne sont respects -  commencer par ceux des Premires nations et des peuples autochtones de notre continent, l'IIe de la Tortue.
Le Canada doit procder  la mise en uvre de l'esprit de la Dclaration des Nations Unies sur les droits des peuples autochtones.

Renforcer et excuter les dcisions prises en 2010 lors des ngociations sur le climat (CdP16) pour instaurer les mesures urgentes et ambitieuses requises mondialement afin d'viter les consquences catastrophiques de la crise climatique et pour nous ajuster et nous adapter aux impacts qui sont dsormais invitables.

Rorienter la mission canadienne en Afghanistan pour miser sur la rduction de la pauvret et le dveloppement, pour renforcer la gouvernance et les institutions de la socit civile, et pour soutenir la formation et le renforcement des forces militaires et policires afghanes, notamment en ce qui a trait au respect et  la protection des droits de la personne.
Respecter les engagements du Canada et inciter les autres nations  respecter les leurs afin d'atteindre les objectifs du Millnaire pour le dveloppement (OMD).
Le NPD s'engage  travailler avec les provinces pour augmenter les prestations du Rgime de pensions du Canada/ Rgie des rentes du Qubec, ayant pour objectif de doubler les prestations;
Le NPD s'engage  travailler avec les provinces afin qu'il soit plus facile pour vous et votre employeur de faire des contributions volontaires  votre rgime de retraite public personnel;

Le NPD s'engage  amender la lgislation fdrale sur les faillites pour que les retraits et les bnficiaires de prestations d'invalidit de longue dure soient au haut de la liste de cranciers lorsque les employeurs se placent sous la protection des tribunaux ou dclarent faillite.
Le NPD s'engage  augmenter le Supplment de revenu garanti annuel  un niveau suffisant dans le premier budget pour que tous les ans du pays puissent immdiatement vivre dans la dignit.

Le NPD s'engage  bonifier la Prestation de compassion de l'assurance-emploi pour qu'elle soit plus flexible et gnreuse, afin de permettre aux familles de prendre jusqu' 6 mois de cong pour prendre soin d'un parent mourant, au lieu des 6 semaines actuelles;

Le NPD s'engage  instaurer une nouvelle Prestation d'aidant naturel, qui s'inspire de la Prestation fiscale pour enfant, afin d'aider les familles  faible et  moyen revenu  mieux faire face au cot des biens essentiels quotidiens lorsqu'elles prennent soin d'un an ou d'un membre de la famille qui n'est pas autonome.

La rponse du Canada  la rcession mondiale a t un modle et une source d'inspiration dans le monde entier.

En novembre 2009, le monde a t confront  une crise conomique imprvue et jamais vue depuis les annes 1930 - la menace de l'effondrement synchronis des systmes financiers et de la confiance des consommateurs et des entreprises.
Pour relever ce dfi extraordinaire, tous les pays industrialiss du monde ont d accuser un dficit temporaire pour maintenir la confiance des entreprises, protger les emplois et stimuler l'conomie.
En 2009, les dirigeants des pays du G20, les principales conomies avances et mergentes du monde, se sont entendus sur cette mesure et ont fix un objectif commun pour des investissements de relance.

Le gouvernement de Stephen Harper a atteint cet objectif pour le Canada - et comme l'indique le bilan du Canada en matire de cration d'emplois depuis le dbut de la rcession mondiale, nos investissements ont port fruits.
Mais nous avons toujours soutenu - et les Canadiens sont d'accord - que nous allons assurer que le dficit ne devienne pas permanent.

En 2010, sous la coprsidence du Premier ministre Stephen Harper, les dirigeants des pays du G20 se sont entendus sur la ncessit de rduire les dficits et les dettes, et d'tablir des objectifs clairs pour y arriver.
Le Canada va atteindre et dpasser ces objectifs, car nous avons fait les bons choix - pas seulement pendant la rcession, mais avant qu'elle ne frappe.
maintenu un budget quilibr;
rembours 37 milliards de dollars sur la dette fdrale;

Grce  ces choix quilibrs et responsables, par contraste avec de nombreux autres pays, le Canada a pu lutter contre la rcession mondiale dans une position de force:
le Canada a dj excut la majeure partie de son programme de relance, et d'ici la fin de 2011, il sera termin;
nous avons assur que nos investissements de relance protgeraient et creraient des emplois immdiatement, sans crer de nouveaux programmes gouvernementaux permanents;
nous sommes sur le point d'liminer notre dficit bien avant le reste du G7 ; et
nous protgeons et amliorons la solide position financire du Canada - nous sortons de la rcession mondiale avec le ratio dette-PIB le moins lev de toutes les principales conomies avances, et de loin.

ou des entreprises qui crent des emplois pour les Canadiens.

recommencer  rembourser la dette fdrale;
continuer  rduire le fardeau fiscal des familles canadiennes; et
continuer  investir dans les priorits.

Le Programme canadien de stabilisation du revenu agricole (PCSRA) est un programme d'assurance-revenu  issu de la premire mouture du Cadre stratgique agricole, qui permet aux producteurs et productrices de bnficier d'une protection contre une variation de leur revenu.

Les producteurs qubcois versent une cotisation  la Financire agricole (qui gre ce programme pour le Qubec) et, selon le taux de couverture voulu, les deux gouvernements se partagent le cot de l'indemnisation8.
L'indemnisation est attribue si le producteur dnote une diffrence mportante entre sa marge de production (ses revenus de l'anne en cours) et sa marge de rfrence.
La marge de rfrence tant la moyenne olympique des marges de production des cinq dernires annes9.

Le problme de ce programme tient au fait que le gouvernement fdral sous-value systmatiquement les cots de production, en fixant ses prix de rfrence en fonction des cots dans des pays o l'agriculture est fortement subventionne.
Or, ces subventions viennent diminuer les cots de production, ce qui fait que les cots sur lesquels le gouvernement se base pour valuer [es compensations ne refltent pas du tout les cots rels.
Les gouvernements du Qubec et du Canada se partageront les indemnisations  20 %-80 % lorsque l'entreprise agricole a un taux de couverture de 70 %.
Ils se partageront les cots  30 %-70 % lorsque le taux de couverture choisi se situe entre 70 % et 85 %.
Finalement, si le taux de couverture est entre 85 % et 100 %, les gouvernements se partagent moiti-moiti le cot des indemnits.
En ne comptabilisant pas la plus leve et la plus faible.
Or, le PCSRA est conu pour pallier les fluctuations, pas pour faire face  une baisse prolonge des prix.

Plusieurs sources ont dnonc les risques importants de torture occasionns par la faiblesse de la premire entente de transfert ngocie sous un gouvernement libral et signe par le gnral Rick Hillier en 2005-
Ce risque connu, le Canada n'a jamais cess de transfrer ses dtenus afghans aux autorits locales, mme si cela pouvait reprsenter une violation des Conventions de Genve.

Le Bloc Qubcois croit que l'aide publique au dveloppement provenant du Canada doit avoir comme objectif la rduction de la pauvret.
C'est pourquoi il a appuy et continuera d'appuyer des initiatives qui assurent que l'aide publique au dveloppement soit destine  rduire la pauvret portant directement atteinte  la vie et  la sant.
Nanmoins, force est de constater que le gouvernement conservateur fait fi de cela.

Mme si la Loi sur la responsabilit en matire d'aide au dveloppement officielle stipule clairement que cette aide doit avoir comme mission la rduction de la pauvret, le gouvernement conservateur a pig dans cette enveloppe pour financer des programmes qui n'ont rien  voir avec la rduction de la pauvret dans les pays en voie de dveloppement.

Par exemple, il a financ un programme d'aide  la rinstallation des immigrantes et des immigrants au Canada, un programme de dploiement d'agents de la GRC  l'tranger, le dveloppement des rseaux de tlcommunications dans des pays en voie de dveloppement, etc.
Le Bloc Qubcois ne s'oppose pas  ces programmes.

Il est nacceptable que le gouvernement canadien utilise son enveloppe d'aide au dveloppement officiel (ADO) pour financer des initiatives et des programmes qui ne servent pas  faire du dveloppement dans les pays pauvres.
Les citoyennes et les citoyens du Qubec et du Canada s'attendent  ce que l'aide serve aux citoyens des pays en voie de dveloppement.

22.1.1 Pour le Bloc Qubcois, l'aide publique au dveloppement devrait servir  financer des programmes et initiatives visant la rduction de la pauvret des habitants les plus vulnrables dans les pays en voie de dveloppement, tel que l'amlioration de la salubrit, l'accs  l'eau potable et la lutte contre la malnutrition.
Le gouvernement canadien s'tait aussi engag  consacrer une enveloppe budgtaire quivalente  0,7 % de son PNB  l'aide publique au dveloppement.
Toutefois,  partir du dbut des annes 1990,  le gouvernement  libral a sabr dans les budgets,  les faisant passer d'un peu moins de 0,5 % en 1991  0,25 % en 2000.
Ils ne reprsentent plus aujourd'hu qu'un maigre 0,3 % du PNB.
En 2003, le Parlement dcidait d'accrotre l'aide trangre de 8 % par anne afin de la doubler d'ici 2010-2011, engagement confirm  nouveau dans les budgets subsquents.
ce rythme avec l'inflation et la croissance du PNB, le Canada ne respectera qu'en 2033 son engagement d'atteindre l'objectif de 0,7 % fix par l'ONU, alors qu'il s'est engag  le faire en 2015.

Lors du budget de 2010, le gouvernement fdral a annonc son intention de plafonner les budgets de l'aide au dveloppement, confirmant ainsi qu'il n'allait pas faire les efforts qu s'imposent pour atteindre l'objectif de 0,7 % du PNB.

Ainsi,  mesure que l'chance de 2015 approche, nous nous voyons forcs d'admettre que l'inaction des gouvernements fdraux successifs rend de plus en plus illusoire la capacit du Canada  respecter cet engagement international.
Nanmoins, l'objectif d'accorder 0,7 % du PNB  l'aide au dveloppement demeure louable.
C'est pourquoi le gouvernement fdral doit prsenter un plan crdible et raliste pour atteindre cet objectif.
Le gouvernement fdral doit donc accorder des hausses budgtaires  son enveloppe d'aide au dveloppement.

De plus, nous avons demand au gouvernement fdral de prsenter dans le budget 2010 un chancier raliste dtaillant les mesures qui pourraient tre mises en uvre afin que le Canada, de concert avec les autres gouvernements, procde  l'imposition d'une taxe sur les transactions financires internationales.
Les recettes gnres pourraient tre alloues  l'aide au dveloppement.

22.2.1 Le Bloc Qubcois demande que le gouvernement fdral mette en place, le plus rapidement possible, un plan raliste visant l'atteinte de la cible fixe par l'ONU, soit de verser 0,7 % du PNB  l'aide publique au dveloppement.
Depuis plusieurs mois, une lourde tendance s'observe et s'installe chez les conservateurs. On
ne peut que s'inquiter du dsengagement important et de la politique de la peur imposs aux organisations non gouvernementales en aide internationale par le gouvernement Harper.
Un dsengagement qui est particulirement marqu face aux besoins des organismes qu soutiennent des positions ne correspondant pas aux vues du gouvernement.

En effet, depuis 2009, plusieurs organismes financs par l'Agence canadienne de dveloppement international (ACDI) doivent patienter plusieurs mois avant d'obtenir une rponse  leur demande de financement, ce qui entrane plusieurs mises  pied, une rvision parfois en profondeur de certains programmes et mme dans plusieurs cas la cessation simple et entire du financement.

Depuis l'arrive au pouvoir des conservateurs, l'ACDI met fin  des partenariats de plusieurs annes auprs d'organismes qui ont prouv au fil des ans leur efficacit et leur professionnalisme, des organismes qui ont dmontr leur importance capitale dans l'espace dmocratique.
Or, le gouvernement conservateur agit comme s'il tait interdit de critiquer ou de remettre en question ses politiques sous peur de trs dures reprsailles.
Cette attitude est inqualifiable et inacceptable.
22.3.1 Le Bloc Qubcois exhorte le gouvernement fdral  accorder aux ONG un financement prvisible et  long terme.
De plus, le gouvernement doit assurer l'indpendance de ces ONG : il ne revient pas  la socit civile de dfendre la politique du gouvernement.
Le 23 fvrier 2009, Le gouvernement conservateur a annonc qu'il allait concentrer son aide bilatrale dans 20 pays prioritaires.
Cela vient changer la liste des pays prioritaires qui avait t mise en place par le gouvernement de Paul Martin, en 2005, lorsque 25 pays avaient t cibls.
En modifiant cette liste, le gouvernement conservateur cesse de prioriser l'Afrique.
En effet, huit pays africains ont t rays de la liste prioritaire, dont le Rwanda, le Niger, le Burkina Faso et le Bnin.
Comparativement  la liste de 2005 qui comportait 14 pays africains, la liste de 200 n'en contient que sept.
De plus, le gouvernement fdral rduit de moiti le nombre des pays de la Francophonie qui bnficieront de l'aide bilatrale du Canada.
La liste de 2005 comportait dix pays membres de la Francophonie, alors que la liste de 200 ne contient que cinq pays membres.

Considrant les liens linguistiques et culturels qui unissent ces pays francophones au Qubec et au Canada, le geste du gouvernement conservateur dmontre son peu de considration  l'gard des francophones d'ici et d'ailleurs.
Parmi les nouveaux pays ajouts  la liste, certains sont mieux nantis que les pays africains retirs.
On y note l'Ukraine, la Colombie, le Prou, le Pakistan et l'Indonsie.
Selon les indicateurs de pauvret, la liste de 2005 comportait plus de pays pauvres que la liste de 200.
22.4.1  Le Bloc Qubcois exhorte le gouvernement fdral  revoir sa liste des pays prioritaires afin de ne pas laisser tomber les pays africains et francophones.
L'ouverture au commerce et la cration de rgles internationales pour contrer le protectionnisme et protger les investissements sont de bonnes choses auxquelles le Bloc Qubcois adhre.

Cela ne signifie pas que les rgles commerciales doivent remettre en cause la capacit des tats  redistribuer la richesse,  protger l'environnement et la culture et assurer  leurs citoyennes et citoyens des services publics fondamentaux comme la sant et l'ducation.
Le cours actuel de la mondialisation, qui est un phnomne porteur de grandes esprances, mais aussi de grandes injustices, doit tre inflchi.
Le Qubec est une nation commerante.
Les exportations internationales et interprovinciales du Qubec reprsentent 51 % de son PIB.
Nos entreprises, en particulier nos entreprises de pointe ne pourraient survivre sur le march intrieur.
Une position protectionniste serait contraire  nos intrts.

C'est la raison pour laquelle le Qubec, et en particulier les souverainistes qubcois, ont massivement approuv l'accord de libre-change avec les tats-Unis puis l'ALNA et que le Bloc Qubcois a t le premier parti  demander une entente de libre-change avec l'Union europenne.
Or, l'environnement commercial s'est considrablement dtrior ces dernires annes.

Entre 2003 et 2009, le Qubec est pass d'un important surplus commercial  un dficit commercial de 21 milliards de dollars13, lequel nous a aussi considrablement appauvris et a affaibli notre secteur manufacturier.
La libralisation des changes ne peut tre profitable que si elle est balise par certaines rgles.
Autrement, elle n'est qu'une course vers le bas.
Longtemps, la politique commerciale canadienne n'a vis qu' accrotre l'accs aux marchs trangers.
De ce point de vue, elle a t un grand succs.
Aujourd'hui, la majorit des produits reprsentant environ 85 % du commerce mondial, circulent librement.

Mais nous sommes maintenant  mme de constater certains effets pervers de cette libralisation dbride : pressions extrmes sur notre industrie, dlocalisations  rabais, accords commerciaux qui sont autant d'encouragements  aller exploiter les populations et l'environnement dans les pays en dveloppement.
L'environnement commercial a chang ces dernires annes et, en ce qui concerne le Qubec, ce n'est pas pour le mieux.
23.1.1 Le Bloc Qubcois propose un changement dans les priorits commerciales du Canada.
Aprs la libralisation des changes, le Canada doit maintenant se concentrer sur l'tablissement de rgles permettant des changes plus quitables.
Un systme commercial qui engendre l'exploitation dans les pays pauvres et le dumping dans [es pays riches n'est pas viable.
L'absence de standards en matire d'environnement ou de droit du travail dans les accords commerciaux exerce une pression norme sur nos industries, particulirement nos industries traditionnelles.

Le Bloc Qubcois estime que le travail des enfants, le travail forc et le dni des droits fondamentaux des travailleuses et des travailleurs constituent une forme de concurrence dloyale, au mme titre, voire davantage, que les subventions  l'exportation ou le dumping.

L'interdiction de ces pratiques est largement accepte  l'chelle internationale, comme en tmoigne l'important niveau d'adhsion aux huit conventions fondamentales de l'Organisation internationale du travail.
Il faut avoir le moyen de se protger contre ces pratiques.
Or, les accords commerciaux et les lois commerciales ne permettent pas de protger nos entreprises et nos travailleurs contre ce dumping social.
Si un pays veut profiter des avantages du libre-change, il devrait en contrepartie accepter un certain nombre de rgles de base notamment dans le domaine des droits sociaux.
Le Qubec, o les industries menaces par la concurrence asiatique sont proportionnellement beaucoup plus prsentes qu'au Canada, est en avance dans ce dbat.

Le Bloc Qubcois presse le gouvernement fdral de rviser ses positions dans les ngociations commerciales pour faire en sorte d'inclure dans les accords commerciaux des clauses prvoyant le respect des accords internationaux relatifs aux droits fondamentaux du travail, de la personne et du respect de l'environnement.

Le Bloc Qubcois considre que le Canada, pour tre crdible sur cette question, doit rapidement adhrer aux grandes conventions de l'Organisation internationale du travail contre les discriminations, le travail forc et le travail des enfants, pour le droit d'association syndicale et la libre ngociation et qu'il contraigne les entreprises canadiennes oeuvrant  l'tranger de respecter les mmes principes des dites conventions.
Seules les entreprises peuvent actuellement dposer des plaintes au Tribunal canadien du commerce extrieur.

Or, dans les cas de dlocalisation, il arrive que nos usines ferment et que nos emplois se perdent parce qu'ils sont victimes de la concurrence dloyale provenant d'une entreprise canadienne prsente  l'tranger.
En pareil cas, l'entreprise d'ici ne dposera videmment pas de plainte; elle dposerait cette plainte contre elle-mme.

Des pratiques dloyales, qui seraient considres comme anticoncurrentielles et interdites si elles taient pratiques sur le march canadien, deviennent ainsi tolres lorsque le produit est fabriqu  l'tranger, tout simplement parce que les lois sont dpasses.

23.3.1 Le Bloc Qubcois prsentera des amendements aux lois commerciales pour permettre aux syndicats de dposer eux-mmes des plaintes au Tribunal canadien du commerce extrieur, notamment pour faire face aux situations o l'entreprise n'en dposera pas parce qu'elle a dlocalis sa production  l'tranger.

Lorsque le Tribunal canadien du commerce extrieur constate que les entreprises subissent un dommage grave et sont menaces par des importations qui augmentent  une vitesse folle il autorise le gouvernement  les protger temporairement (pour un maximum de cinq ans), le temps qu'elles se modernisent et qu'elles affrontent la concurrence trangre.
Ces mesures prvues dans les accords commerciaux, s'appellent des mesures de sauvegarde.

Jusqu' maintenant, chaque fois que le Tribunal du commerce a recommand au gouvernement de prendre des mesures de sauvegarde pour donner aux industries un peu de temps pour s'adapter, le gouvernement fdral a toujours refus.
Dans tous les cas, il s'agissait d'entreprises fortement prsentes au Qubec, comme les bicyclettes, le textile ou le vtement.

23.4.1 Le Bloc Qubcois pressera le gouvernement de respecter les dcisions du Tribunal canadien du commerce extrieur lorsqu'il constate qu'un secteur industriel subit un dommage grave du fait des importations accrues et qu'il recommande de prendre des mesures de sauvegarde.

Si le projet de Zone de libre-change des Amriques est sur la glace et que la ronde de Doha  l'OMC est moribonde, ce n'est pas parce que le systme multilatral est inefficace, mais bien parce que les bases de ngociation sont mauvaises.
Plusieurs pays semblent considrer que les concessions qu'on leur demande sont plus importantes que les bienfaits qu'ils esprent tirer d'un ventuel accord.
Si tout le monde a l'impression d'y perdre au change, c'est qu'il y a un problme.
Globalement, le systme multilatral a t d'une redoutable efficacit.
Les accords visant  libraliser le commerce ont compltement chang la face du monde.
Aujourd'hui, la majorit des produits, reprsentant 85 % du commerce mondial, circulent librement.
Avec l'Accord gnral sur les tarifs douaniers et le commerce (GATT) de 1947 et ses successeurs, il n'est plus ncessaire d'envahir un pays pour avoir accs  ses ressources ou son march. Le
GATT, puis l'OMC, ont sonn le glas des empires et probablement vit bien des guerres.
C'est un gain norme.
Le temps est venu de corriger les effets pervers de la libralisation du commerce et de veiller  ce que les changes commerciaux soient source de progrs pour tous.
Or, un accord bilatral de libre-change avec un pays en particulier peut libraliser davantage le commerce, mais il ne permet pas d'dicter des rgles permettant de civiliser le commerce.
Ce magnifique chantier ne peut s'accomplir qu'en contexte multilatral.
23.5.1 Le Bloc Qubcois raffirme sa confiance dans le systme multilatral, seul lieu o il est possible de travailler  l'adoption de rgles permettant de favoriser une mondialisation plus quitable.
Le gouvernement Harper tend  dlaisser la voie multilatrale en matire de commerce, comme il est tent de le faire en matire d'affaires trangres.
Il a entrepris des ngociations d'accords de libre-change avec 29 pays, dont plusieurs ont t conclus.
En aucun cas, le gouvernement n'a procd  une analyse des impacts conomiques de ces accords.
Doctrinaire dans ses positions commerciales, il estime que le libre-change est toujours bon, peu importe le partenaire.
C'est ainsi qu'il a conclu un accord avec la Colombie, un des pays o les droits de la personne sont le moins respects, et avec le Panama un paradis fiscal.
Le Bloc Qubcois n'appuiera d'ventuels accords bilatraux de libre-change que s'il est convaincu qu'ils sont bnfiques pour l'conomie qubcoise.

Le Bloc Qubcois tient  ce que les nouveaux accords de libre-change contiennent des clauses excutoires exigeant le respect de standards minimums en matire de droits de la personne, de droit du travail et de respect de l'environnement.
Le Bloc Qubcois s'oppose fermement  la conclusion d'accords de libre-change avec des paradis fiscaux et des pays ayant un mauvais bilan en matire de respect des droits.

veillera  ce que des clauses assurant le respect de l'environnement, des normes minimales concernant le travail et les droits fondamentaux soient incluses pour permettre une mondialisation juste et quitable pour tout le monde ;
considre que la Convention sur la protection et la promotion de la diversit des expressions culturelles de l'UNESCO et le principe de l'exception culturelle doivent tre respects dans leur intgralit;
cj s'assurera que les marchs publics jugs stratgiques pour l'conomie du Qubec soient protgs et que les concessions soient rciproques entre les parties ;
d) veillera  ce que le mcanisme de gestion de l'offre en agriculture ne soit pas menac.
Les investissements directs trangers sont en croissance exponentielle.

Pour crer un environnement prvisible et s'assurer qu'un investisseur tranger ne se fera pas dpossder de son bien ou nationaliser sans compensation, les pays concluent des traits relatifs  la protection des investissements.
C'est tout  fait normal et le Bloc Qubcois appuie la conclusion de tels traits.

En revanche, on a assist  une drive avec la conclusion du chapitre 11 de l'ALNA, lequel permet aux multinationales de provoquer elles-mmes des conflits commerciaux et de poursuivre les gouvernements qui adoptent des mesures, notamment environnementales, qui auraient pour effet de rduire leurs profits.
23.7.1 Le Bloc Qubcois s'oppose  la conclusion d'accords sur la protection des investissements bass sur le modle du chapitre 11 de l'ALNA.
The Greens believe that everyone has a right to timely, high-quality health care, regardless of their income.
The fairest and most efficient way to achieve this is through the public health system.
We strongly support Medicare, and propose an increase in the Medicare levy to cover essential services that are not presently covered.
These services include dentistry, physiotherapy, certain areas of mental health, and alternative and complementary therapies that have been proven to be effective.
The Greens will abolish the $2.5 billion per annum Private Health Insurance Rebate.
The money saved will be redirected to where it is most needed  public health (including preventative healthcare and hospitals)
Our approach to health care is holistic.
This means focusing on eradicating the causes of ill health, such as poverty, inadequate housing, over-work or lack of work, and air and water pollution.
The link between poverty and disease and premature death is well established.
The most obvious example in Australia is the appalling health of Indigenous peoples.
Redressing this is a priority for the Greens.
The Australian Greens are committed to protecting our old growth and high conservation value forests.
We need to establish a comprehensive reserve system that represents all forest types  from rainforests and tall wet forests to dry forests and woodlands.
These forests play an important role in water, soil and biodiversity conservation.
We would immediately end the export of woodchips from native forests.
Our plan for the timber industry moves wood production away from native forests into plantations (which already supply over 75% of our wood needs) on cleared land.
It promotes paper recycling
and incorporates retraining and other assistance to workers.
Tasmanias internationally renowned forests are being destroyed at the greatest rate in history.
Tasmania exports more than twice as many woodchips as all the other states combined.
The old growth and high conservation value forests of Tasmania  the Styx, Tarkine, Blue Tier and Western Tiers  must be protected.
Across Australia, the Greens are working to protect forests and wildlife threatened by logging and woodchipping.
These areas include Victorias Otways, Central Highlands and East Gippsland, Western Australias southwest and areas across NSW.
The Greens would also safeguard the savannahs and tropical forests of the north and arid woodlands that span Australias heart.
The Greens will work for an immediate end to broadscale landclearing, which destroys the habitat of native species and causes major land degradation problems such as salinity.
We seek a halt to illegal landclearing and the closure of loopholes that allow ongoing clearing of remnant vegetation.
We support the creation by 2012 of a national system of Marine Protected Areas representing all marine ecosystems.
At least 30% of each Protected Area should be no take (fishing prohibited).
Quarantine measures need strengthening to prevent the introduction of exotic plants, animals and diseases which increasingly threaten Australias native species and ecosystems.
Australians are the worlds highest per capita users of water.
Most of this water is used for irrigation (75%); urban and industrial use accounts for 20%.

Between 1985 and 1997 total water use increased by 65% and it is increasingly evident from stressed and degraded rivers, floodplains and wetlands that we are using water well beyond sustainable levels.
The Greens aim to protect our remaining natural rivers,
to restore freshwater ecosystems to health by giving them enough water at the right times,
to share extracted water fairly
and to use it more efficiently.
As a priority we want governments to commit to providing a minimum additional 1500 GL per annum for environmental flows to the Murray River.
We will campaign to keep all major water resources and infrastructure in public ownership.
The Greens believe that a strong public education system is the key to creating a fair, successful and cohesive society,
and that everyone has the right to free, high-quality public education and training.
To achieve this, we would massively increase funding for all levels of public education.
The Greens are committed to providing free, public early childhood education and childcare places for all Australian children in the year preceding compulsory schooling.
We believe that delivery of early childhood services should be better regulated, with minimum standards of care and education
and greatly improved pay and conditions for early childhood professionals.
The Greens want to stop the growth in public funding of private schools
and increase funding for public education.
Specifically, we wish to improve pay and professional development opportunities for teachers and reduce class sizes.
We believe that public money used to fund the wealthiest elite private schools should be redirected to a national program to support disadvantaged public schools
The Greens want a public inquiry, to work out a fair replacement for the Australian Governments inequitable private school funding formulae,
and ensure that non-government schools receive public funding only if they meet standards for transparency, accountability and educational standards.
The Greens are working to significantly increase Commonwealth funding of TAFE, to restore the breadth and duration of courses, and to provide better conditions for teachers and students.
High quality, comprehensive, public education should be free to students at all levels, including university.
The Greens believe that higher education funding is an investment in the future and not a cost.
Every government dollar invested in higher education brings a return of more than $2 to Australian society.
Abolishing university fees and the HECS system.
Abolition of HECS would only cost around $2 billion each year - less than the total value of the $4 a week tax cut delivered in the 2003 budget.

Significantly increasing university funding to maintain the quality of teaching and independence of research, to reduce class sizes, to increase the total number of students, and to eliminate reliance on corporations for sponsorship
Improving student income support
Preserving compulsory student association fees to keep university life affordable and supportive for all students
The freedom for staff to organise collectively, to pursue research that is in the public interest and to be represented by their union
The war on terrorism isnt working.
Following George Bushs foreign policy has made us less safe.
We are contributing to the growing anger towards the West across the Middle East and the Islamic world.
Only by addressing the causes of terrorism, not the symptoms, can we hope to live in a safer world.
The first step is developing fair and just international relations with other peoples and governments around the world.
By working for peace through justice we can create genuine security for Australia.
An independent foreign and defence policy
that opposes pre-emptive strikes
An aid program targeted towards the elimination of poverty as the primary objective
Rejection of international trade agreements that undermine poor countries
Ending nuclear warship visits,
removing bases which might contribute to nuclear war,
and dropping support for the dangerous national missile defence which threatens a new arms race
Democratisation and strengthening of the United Nations
We cannot defend freedom at home by removing those freedoms  denying civil rights only diminishes our democracy.
Repealing new ASIO powers and other laws that diminish civil rights
Reasonable measures such as increased airport security and the use of the criminal law to prosecute terrorist crimes
The end of the Cold War has not brought peace.
The pursuit of military and economic dominance by the United States at the expense of international law and human rights is destabilising the world.
We need a new relationship with the United States, including one that ends Australias role as Deputy Sheriff in the Asia-Pacific.
The illegal invasion and occupation of Iraq is proving a failure and a disaster.
Military occupation is the problem, not the solution.
The Greens believe Australian troops must be brought home now
and Iraqis allowed their self-determination.
Instead, Australia should commit funds for a genuine reconstruction of Iraq,
under the control of a democratically elected Iraqi government.
Immediately withdraw Australian troops from Iraq
and provide significant aid for Iraqi national reconstruction
Cancel arms contracts that further entrench the Australian defence forces within the US alliance, such as new tanks, expensive fighter aircraft and new warships
Support a real peace process for Israel and Palestine as a prerequisite for peace across the Middle East
Require parliamentary approval before any overseas military deployment
Reduce the levels of defence spending
while maintaining an adequate defence force
Australia needs a new style of economic management, where people and the environment matter.
Currently, more than two million Australians live in poverty  a national disgrace.
To restore government control of the economy, we will halt wholesale privatisations and keep essential services in public ownership. The Greens will also:
Use government bonds to finance public infrastructure
Increase the regulation of banks, insurance companies and auditing
Stop companies gaining monopoly control of markets
Ensure companies fulfil their obligations to their workers by introducing a compulsory government-run employer levy that will guarantee workers entitlements

The global economy is increasingly volatile, with currencies fluctuating wildly, many countries suffering from crippling foreign debts and nearly half the worlds population living on less than $US2 per day.
Fair trade not free trade  we reject the Free Trade Agreement with the USA
Radical reform of the World Trade Organisation, World Bank and International Monetary Fund to make them more socially and environmentally responsible
and their abolition if this cant be achieved
Cancelling all Third World debt
Introducing a Tobin tax on currency transactions
Australias tax system is increasing the gap between the haves and have-nots.
The Greens want to see the system made fairer
and used to provide excellent public services in health, education and other areas.
We also wish to protect the environment, by taxing waste and pollution.
Ensure that high-income earners pay their fair share
Bias income tax rates to provide relief to low income earners
End the tax rorts that apply to investments in Australia
Reintroduce inheritance taxes on estates (excluding charitable bequests and inherited farms) worth over $2 million
To ensure that companies pay their fair share of tax, we will increase company tax rates to 33%
and limit the tax deductibility of executive payouts.
The Greens is the only major party that has consistently opposed the GST.
We will phase it out and replace it with fair taxes.
The Greens will hold a Royal Commission into the distribution of wealth in our country,
and will introduce a genuine progress indicator (incorporating social and environmental sustainability) into Australias national account statistics.
Climate change is upon us.
Nine of the ten hottest years on record have been since 1990, and the Earth is expected to warm by a further 1-5C this century.
The consequences of climate change will include rising sea levels and more extreme storms, floods and droughts.
In Australia, burning coal for electricity is the biggest single source of greenhouse gas pollution.
By conserving energy and switching to renewable energy, we will create jobs and radically reduce Australias contribution to global warming.
We should ratify the Kyoto Protocol immediately
and make Australia an international clean energy leader, reducing Australias greenhouse gas emissions to 80% below 1990 levels by 2050.
Introducing mandatory targets for reducing emissions
Ensuring that buildings and appliances become rapidly more energy efficient by introducing mandatory standards and labeling
Establishing a Sun Fund to help farmers and others in rural and regional Australia take up energy conservation and renewable energy
Phasing out coal-fired electricity in Australia by 2050, as part of the switch to renewable energy
Introducing a carbon levy to finance investment in energy conservation, public transport and renewable energy
The Australian Greens have a vision for a uniquely Australian agricultural landscape, in which profitable and ecologically sustainable agriculture sustains vibrant rural communities.
Expands Australias organic farming sector
Has no significant negative impacts on Australias soils, water quality and biodiversity
Minimises the use of non-renewable energy, agrichemicals (including pesticides and fertilisers) and irrigation
Ensures sustainable use of groundwater resources
Takes into account natural climate variability and potential climate change
The Greens will offer financial assistance for implementing ecologically sustainable farming systems and conservation on private land.
We will also remove public funding which supports degrading practices.
We oppose genetic engineering (GE) of food and fibre crops as unnecessary and unsafe.

The health risks associated with eating food produced using gene technology remain poorly understood, but the environmental risks are clear - the use of GE in farming risks irreversibly contaminating natural and agricultural gene pools.
There are also economic risks - our farmers rely on their crops GE-free status to maintain sales in key Australian export markets including Europe, Asia and the Middle East.
The nuclear fuel cycle creates long-lived radioactive waste and almost permanent environmental contamination.
The Greens believe that society must exercise extreme caution to ensure the protection of all life forms from the effects of radiation.
End uranium mining and the export of uranium from Australia
Close the nuclear facility at Lucas Heights
and prohibit the construction of any new reactors in Australia
Oppose a radioactive waste dump in South Australia
and store existing nuclear waste above ground at a single storage facility in each state or territory so it can be monitored continuously
Close Australias ports and territorial waters to nuclear-powered vessels
Promote an effective international nuclear weapons convention banning the development, production, stockpiling, use and threat of nuclear weapons
Encourage states that currently possess nuclear weapons to dismantle them
Although medical radioisotopes are currently produced in nuclear reactors, some can now be produced using non-reactor technologies.
The Greens support more research into the use of such technologies.
The Greens propose a 10-year $14 billion Renew Australia plan to upgrade Australias ailing public transport services, financed by government guaranteed Green Bonds.
We would spend $4 billion on modernising and upgrading the interstate rail system,
helping to shift freight from road to rail, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, air pollution and accidents.
We would spend $10 billion on urban public transport to upgrade and extend urban rail and tramways,
connect train and bus services,
give buses and trams on-road priority,
and provide safe and continuous bicycle and pedestrian networks.
This would be coupled with service improvements such as integrating bus and train timetables and increasing their speed and frequency.
We would reduce demand for car travel by encouraging the co-location of amenities and services with key points in the public transport network and by:
Ending tax subsidies for company cars and putting an import duty on off-road vehicles
Investigating socially equitable forms of congestion charges and other innovative user pays mechanisms
Restoring indexation of fuel tax and converting it to a carbon levy
Closing the loopholes that have allowed the Commonwealth to fund urban freeways
The Greens oppose new airports near residential areas.
A new airport for Sydney should be built outside the Sydney Basin (not at Wilton)
and should eventually replace Kingsford Smith Airport.
The Australian Greens have a vision for a society where everyone can balance work, family and leisure.
The goal of full employment
A legislated shorter working week
Fair pay and conditions
The recognition of unpaid work, such as caring for children, elderly people and people with disabilities, done outside the formal economy
Equal opportunity programs and fair treatment for every employee
The role of unions as the democratic expression of working people
The right of unions and workers to take industrial action to protect and promote their legitimate interests
The highest standards of occupational health and safety
Permanent jobs not casual jobs
The traditional conciliation and arbitration role of the Industrial Relations Commission
18 weeks of paid replacement earnings up to the average federal wage (but no less than the federal minimum)
A further 34 weeks of unpaid leave
A right to return to work part-time
This would provide replacement earnings for most women;
cover many people working as casuals, on contracts, in seasonal work and the self-employed;
allow partners to share the period of leave;
and cover adoptions.
Social justice is one of the four principles of the Australian Greens.
We seek to ensure that all Australians can live with dignity by:
Eradicating the causes of poverty
Sharing the nations economic wealth fairly
Investing in public services that benefit everyone
The current social welfare system fails to recognise that there is not enough paid work for everyone
or that there are other useful ways to contribute to society.
The Greens support the investigation of a guaranteed adequate income (GAI) scheme.
It would be set at a level that allows people to fully participate in society
and would be designed to encourage recipients to earn income.
It would get rid of the poverty traps that occur when people receiving income support move into paid work.
The Greens support reforming the current social security system to simplify and align all payments for adults and young people,
link changes in payment rates to increases in average weekly earnings,
and replace punitive activity tests with incentives for participation.

We will work for the adoption of a commonly agreed benchmark to measure poverty in Australia so that income support and other government programs can work effectively to prevent poverty, social inequity and exclusion.
The Greens recognise that Indigenous Australians, as First Peoples, have a specific and unique cultural relationship with this country.
We support self-determination, reconciliation and justice.
To achieve these aims, Indigenous people need to control their own affairs.
The Greens support Indigenous self-determination.
Indigenous peoples and their communities are best equipped to develop and implement appropriate mechanisms for self-determination and governance.
Indigenous people must have the right to determine how services such as health, education and housing are provided,
and these services should be adequately funded by governments.
We must recognise and address the wrongs of our past and present.
The Greens are committed to an apology to the Stolen Generations and dealing with unfinished business.
Australia must acknowledge the truth of our history and build a shared story to move forward.
Government must support the preservation and revival of Indigenous language, law and culture.
The Greens are committed to addressing social justice for Indigenous Australians.
This requires political will to implement the many recommendations from past inquiries, including the Royal Commission into Black Deaths in Custody.
The Greens are committed to increasing the Land Acquisition Fund
and implementing a Social Justice package for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.
We will work collaboratively to improve health, education and employment opportunities.
The Greens do not label asylum seekers illegal immigrants.
Many asylum seekers have had no opportunity to apply to immigrate through official procedures.
Those fleeing oppressive regimes take enormous and courageous risks, and deserve to be treated humanely and fairly.
The Australian Greens support a fair go for asylum seekers:
No mandatory detention once medical, identity and security checks are completed
House asylum seekers in reception centres where entry and exit are unrestricted
Provide access to high quality and culturally appropriate legal, education and health services
No excision of any part of Australia from the Australian Migration Zone
Abolish the temporary protection category of visa
Grant permanent resident status to all those currently holding a temporary protection visa
We believe that the presence in Australia of people of many cultural backgrounds enriches our society.
Our immigration policy is non-discriminatory on the grounds of race, nationality, religion, language, gender, sexual preference, disability, age and wealth.
The relationship between people and environments is complex.
The Australian Greens support a population policy based on respects for human rights and social justice as well as ecological limits.
Australias system of democracy needs an overhaul to bring it into the twenty-first century.
Acknowledge the prior occupation and ownership of Australia by Indigenous people
and provide for a treaty of reconciliation
Remove the barriers which prevent millions of Australians from standing for Parliament, including public servants and holders of dual citizenship
Incorporate a Bill of Rights and Responsibilities
Give the Commonwealth explicit responsibility for issues of national and international importance, including the environment
We would move quickly to establish the Republic of Australia, with a two-stage decision-making process:
First, a non-binding plebiscite asking whether Australians want a republic with an Australian head of state
Second, a series of conventions and discussions to develop models and devise a broad program of constitutional innovation, followed by a referendum to determine the form of the Australian republic
Getting rid of corporate donations and their corrupting influence by improving public funding of elections
Introducing proportional representation for the House of Representatives
Giving young people between the ages of 16 and 18 the option to vote and the right to hold public office
Advances for women, won as a result of struggles over many decades, have suffered alarmingly in recent years.
The Greens want to see programs and services for women restored and strengthened.
The Australian Greens will strongly defend womens access to affordable and safe abortion services.
On average, one in five women will experience sexual assault at some time during their life.
The Greens will ensure sufficient funding for educational programs, beginning at an early age for both boys and girls, on sexual violence and relationships.
The Greens recognise womens right to equal pay,
safer communities,
freedom from sexual exploitation
and the right to undertake the career path of their choice.
Freedom of sexuality and gender identity are fundamental human rights.
We are proud of our track record in fighting for the rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender people and people with intersex conditions (LGBTI) everywhere,
and we will continue to fight for equal access to adoption, fostering, artificial insemination and in vitro fertilisation procedures.

We will also continue to support the right of all people to assume their self-identified sex and gender, make fully informed choices about their lives and access appropriate medical intervention if required.
The Greens Same Sex Relationships Bill before the Parliament would ensure people in same sex relationships have all the same rights as people in heterosexual relationships.

The Greens are committed to ensuring that young people have secure and meaningful employment, access to affordable housing, good public transport, quality public education and financial support, and social opportunities that enable them to lead creative and sustainable lifestyles.
We will work to remedy the extreme social and economic disadvantage faced by many young Indigenous Australians and young people of non-English speaking backgrounds.
We will ensure that employment and social services meet the needs of regional and remote communities, where youth unemployment is especially high.
We support preventative strategies which stop young people from being unnecessarily entangled in the criminal justice system,
and high quality care for young people who are victims of abuse, neglect or exploitation.
We will research and implement measures which have been effective in reducing youth suicide in other countries.
The Greens support a greater voice for young people in Australian politics.
We will give young people aged 16 and over the option to vote and the right to hold public office.

Animals are now exploited on an unprecedented scale due to expansion of the worlds human population, new technologies for the mass production of animals and animal products, and the increase in demand for cosmetics and pharmaceuticals.
Protection, restoration and extension of natural habitats for Australian native animals
Prohibition of live animal exports for consumption
Phasing out of intensive animal farming practices which do not treat animals ethically
Abolition of the use or display of wild animals in circuses
A compulsory labelling system to allow consumers to identify cruelty-free products
Arts and artists are vital for our society and economy, yet with governments basing policies on narrow economics, they struggle to survive.
The ABC is one of the most important producers and disseminators of culture and information in Australia and must remain an independent and comprehensive national broadcaster.
Increased funding to the arts and artists,
including Indigenous artists
Protection for the property and moral rights of artists
Exemption of the arts from free trade agreements
Increased funding for the ABC and SBS
Increased local content in broadcasting and new media
and support for community radio and TV.
My message today comes straight from the people of Australia.
It's a message to the people, drawn from the strength and wisdom of the people.
From the Australians I've been privileged to meet, across the vast suburbs and regions of our nation, over the past 10 months.
And the millions of their fellow-Australians they represent.
Today I want to speak on their behalf.
I want to talk about opportunity, responsibility and honesty - the key themes of this great campaign for a new Labor Government.
This message comes from the heart - the big heart of the Australian people themselves.
It's from the people - and all that I have learned about their concerns, their needs and their aspirations for the future - that I see a real urgency in this campaign.
The urgent need to change now.
The urgent need for an Australian Labor Government.
Unless we change now, it will be too late to save Medicare - too late to increase bulk-billing and improve our public hospital system.
Unless we change now, it will be too late for the fairness of our education system - too late for needs-based funding in our schools and new opportunities at TAFE and university.
Unless we change now, it will be too late for the families under financial pressure - too late to solve the family debt crisis and deliver tax relief for all Australian taxpayers.

Unless we change now, it will be too late for the security and safety of our nation - too late to shift policy and resources to our part of the world, getting it right in Asia in the fight against terror.
And unless we change now, it will be too late for the basic decency and honesty of government in this country -
too late to restore truth in government and end the deceit and buck-passing of the Howard years.
Australia needs these changes.
And Labor is ready to make them, before it's too late.
I have listened to the Australian people, and now I have the privilege of speaking for them - in presenting the key elements of Labor's plan for the future.
Our plan for a stronger, safer and fairer Australia.
Our plan to grow the Australian economy
by investing more in skills and education,
by creating incentive and rewarding hard work,
by reforming the Trade Practices Act
and helping small business.

Our plan to use this prosperity well, to ensure that the hard work and enterprise of the Australian people delivers a social benefit: the world-class health and education services we need for the future of our children.
Our plan for uniting the Australian people around a sense of common purpose and participation in the whole work and life of the community.
Our plan for new opportunities for all Australians.
Our big ambition for this great country of ours.
And given the size of these tasks - saving Medicare, lifting educational opportunity and securing the nation - Australia needs a Prime Minister fully committed to the long haul.
We need a Prime Minister who trusts the people, who tells them the truth about the great issues of war and peace.
And when things go wrong, a Prime Minister who is big enough to take responsibility and not blame others.
We need a Prime Minister who will take the people into his confidence, not least about his own intentions.
It's urgent to bring a new energy, a new accountability to Australia's biggest job.
And that's the difference between Labor and the Liberals.
We've got a great public plan for the future.
Mr Howard's got a private plan for retirement.
I'm ready to lead.
He's ready to leave.
I have a simple goal: to give Australia a government as good as the Australian people themselves, to bring new drive and ideas to the leadership of the nation.
Mr Howard, too, has a simple goal: he wants the electorate to help him beat Bob Hawke in the Guinness Book of Records.
That's the big difference in this campaign.
Mr Howard sees it as a lap of honour.
I see it as an honour to serve, to muster all my passion and commitment for the long-term service of the Australian people.
I say: if you truly love this country, if you truly respect its people, no one could run to be Prime Minister with anything less than a full commitment to the job.
I couldn't do it.
And I don't know how Mr Howard can claim to believe in Australia when he refuses to be honest and open with the Australian people themselves.
But perhaps we shouldn't be too hard on him.
There is, of course, one promise Mr Howard has kept in full.
There's one goal he and his Coalition colleagues have pursued relentlessly for eight years - and that's the destruction of Medicare.
This has been one of the great ding-dong battles of Australian public life.
A battle of principle on health policy.
Labor investing in public health care.
The Coalition pursuing the privatisation of health - a system based on private insurance and private care.
Labor investing in one tier of quality health care for all Australians.
The Coalition preferring a two tier system - private health insurance for the top tier and a second class service for everyone else.
That's what they believe in.
Last year Mr Howard was asked about his preferred health policy.
And he said that he liked the system we had at the beginning of the 1970s.
None of us should forget what he was talking about.
That was a time when a large number of Australian families had no health insurance - public or private.
They had to make that terrible choice in life between food on the table and the health care of their children.
It's the reason why Labor Governments introduced Medibank and then Medicare - to provide a decent level of public health insurance for all Australians.
A health system based on the medical needs of the patient, not the size of their bank account.
John Howard has opposed Medicare ever since.
When he first led the Liberal Party he said that he wanted to ''take a scalpel to Medicare''.
Last month his Deputy John Anderson said that country people wanted and needed a two-tier health system.
Well, that's what this election is all about.
It's a referendum on the future of Medicare.
Do we want the Coalition to take us further down the American road of privatised health - a two tier system?
Do we want to give John Howard another chance to put his scalpel into Medicare?
Or do we want a Labor Government with a plan to save Medicare?
Just one tier.
One world-class health care system for all Australians.
We set up this system, we're proud of it and we're going to bring it back to its full health.
Labor believes in Medicare.
It's good public policy.
But it also says something special about who we are, about the things that make us uniquely Australian.
It says that in our country, if you get sick then someone will care for you.
It says that the Australian people look out for each other.
That we help our mates and those in need.
No one gets left behind.
No one gets left without decent hospital care, without the availability of a bulk-billing doctor.
That's what makes it Medicare.
And that's why Labor believes in it.
It's universal.
It's for the many, not just the few.
The Liberals talk about a safety net.
But you don't need a safety net unless you've turned the health system into a highwire act and families are in danger of falling off.
Labor doesn't believe in a safety net.
We believe in Medicare.
And we'll never surrender, we'll never give up on increasing the rate of bulk-billing.
We want to get it back to a national rate of 80 per cent.
That's why a Labor Government will: Immediately increase the patient rebate by $5 for every bulk- billed consultation;
Provide incentive payments of up to $22,500 for doctors who reach bulk-billing targets;
Introduce Medicare After-Hours - GP clinics and services that stretch well into the night;
And we'll train thousands of extra doctors and nurses around Australia.
In communities where bulk-billing has collapsed, we'll provide Medicare Teams - salaried doctors and nurses to deliver bulk- billing services.
Labor will also work with the States to upgrade our public hospital system.
When the Coalition finds an extra dollar in the budget, they spend it on private health.
Labor's top priority is public health - investing in public hospitals, reducing out-of-pocket expenses and cutting waiting lists.
The Howard Government has taken almost a billion dollars out of public hospital funding to the States.
Labor will put it back in.
We'll invest an extra $350 million in capital improvements for emergency departments - clearing the backlog, getting the patients off trolleys and into hospital beds.
We'll also provide an extra 2.4 million specialist treatments for outpatients in public hospitals, free-of-charge.
This is Labor's vision for the health system.
Families who can find a bulk-billing doctor.
Patients who move quickly through emergency departments and then have available to them the best doctors, nurses and medical technology - services free-of-charge in public hospitals.
Quality health care for all.
To make this vision real, we always need to do more.
Mr Howard is waging war on Medicare.
I want to build a fortress around it.
In particular, we must do more for our senior citizens.
I can't stomach a system where elderly Australians are left on hospital waiting lists for long periods of time.
Our senior citizens have served this country well.
They've defended it during times of war.
They've won peace and built our prosperity.
The measure of our civilisation, the test for Australians of my generation, is how we treat them in return.
You know, I'm part of the lucky generation.
We've fought no world wars.
We've seen no depressions.
We've enjoyed a national dividend of peace and prosperity secured by older Australians.
Surely now, it's time to say thank you.
And to treat our senior citizens as they have treated us.
With honour and respect.
And the best way of honouring their service to Australia is to give them the world's best health system.
To get them off waiting lists and into hospital beds as quickly as possible.
Today I can announce the greatest extension in Federal responsibility for hospital care in this country since the introduction of Medibank 30 years ago.
A Federal Labor Government will take full responsibility for the hospital costs of Australians aged 75 and over.
We will ensure that they can access a hospital bed - public or private - straight away.
No more delays.
No more waiting lists for our oldest Australians.
This is an important extension of the universal coverage of Medicare.
We call it Medicare Gold.
In some parts of Australia, our senior citizens can wait up to 12 months for hip, knee and eye operations.
Medicare Gold will give them a hospital bed straight away.
Public hospitals will receive additional funding to improve the services they provide for Australians aged over 75.
Labor will also pay for private hospital beds, under agreements finalised with the private hospital system.
As a result, senior Australians will no longer need to take out private health insurance for hospital care.
The costs will be covered by a Federal Labor Government.
Medicare Gold is a great advance for our national health system.
It ends the old, inefficient divide between public versus private hospitals and Commonwealth versus State funding.
It will also deliver significant benefits for Australians under 75 - taking the pressure off public hospitals and reducing the cost of private health insurance.
People aged 75 and over make up five per cent of the private insurance pool, but account for 23 per cent of hospital benefits paid out by the private funds.
Under Medicare Gold, these costs will be met by the Commonwealth, allowing the funds to reduce their hospital insurance premiums by at least 12 per cent.
Labor will regulate to ensure these savings are passed onto the public.
That's the advantage of Medicare Gold:
Extending Medicare into universal hospital coverage - public and private - for Australians aged 75 and over.
Reducing hospital waiting lists for all age groups.
And providing better value for money with private hospital insurance - savings of more than 12 per cent.
It's a gold-plated Medicare system - Medicare Gold.
And only a Labor Government will deliver it.
There's another waiting list we must also confront.
Another service we must provide to our senior citizens.
Currently there are more than 500,000 Australians, most of them elderly, waiting for months and years, just to have their teeth fixed.
Mr Howard axed the previous Federal program and said that the States had to look after dental care.
I say: it's a national responsibility,
part of the care and consideration we owe our senior Australians.
That's why a Labor Government will create a national dental program: a $300 million investment with an extra 1.3 million dental treatments for aged pensioners and health card holders.
This will clear away the existing backlog and give our senior citizens what they deserve: the care of a civilised society in getting their teeth fixed up.
They've served our country well.
Now we must honour and serve their needs, through Medicare Gold and a national dental program.
When I became Labor Leader I said that I would listen to the Australian people.
I said that I would open up the political process - a new politics of community forums and consultation.
I promised to reform politicians' entitlements, starting with the parliamentary superannuation scheme.
And I delivered.
Many of the people coming to our community forums have been senior Australians.
Age pensioners have told me how they're struggling financially under the Howard Government.
Their incomes are fixed, but the cost of living keeps on rising - with higher health costs, bank fees and the impact of the GST.
They're frustrated that the government only adjusts their pension twice a year.
I say: six months is too long to wait for assistance.
It's too long to wait for a cost of living increase in the pension.
I've listened to these concerns and now I want to deliver a solution.
A Labor Government will increase the pension four times a year.
We'll introduce quarterly indexation - increases in June and December, in addition to March and September.
These new arrangements will start on June 20 next year, with an increase in the fortnightly pension of around $5 for singles and $8 for couples.
The cost of living doesn't stand still for six months between pension increases.
The pension shouldn't be frozen either.
Labor will index it every quarter.
We'll ease the financial pressure on Australia's pensioners.
Our policy will benefit Age Pensioners, DVA Service Pensioners, Carer Pensioners, Disability Pensioners, Sole Parent Pensioners, Wife and Widow Pensioners.
There's another group of senior Australians who have been coming to my community forums.
They're grandparents who, late in life, have taken care and custody of their grandchildren.
Having moved into retirement, they now face the renewed challenge of raising young children - with all the costs and pressure this involves.
These grandparents deserve our support.
They're providing love and devotion to children in need.
The Australian Government needs to provide them with new forms of financial support.
Today I can announce that Labor will introduce a new Grandparenting Allowance, worth $20 per week for each child.
This will benefit over 27,000 grandparents around Australia who have primary care of their grandchildren.
And I say: they deserve every cent of it.
They're unsung heroes in our society.
This is one of the great goals of Labor's campaign: lifting the financial pressure on the families and senior Australians doing it tough.
Just four months ago, on Budget night, these were the forgotten Australians:
The hard workers on 30, 40 and 50 thousand dollars a year who missed out on a tax cut.
The pensioners and self-funded retirees who were also ignored.
Well, Labor hasn't forgotten them.
Our Tax and Family Plan will ease the squeeze on middle Australia.
It will put incentive and reward for effort back into the Australian economy.
Under Labor all those Australian taxpayers earning under $52,000 a year (including self-funded retirees) will get a tax cut of up to $8 a week - $416 a year.
With the rising cost of buying a home and raising a family, people earning over $80,000 a year also need incentive.
That's why Labor will lift the threshold for the top marginal tax rate.
Plus we'll help families with a better family payments system.
Combining payments into one, simpler scheme and raising the point at which the means test starts from $33,000 to $50,000.
For a typical middle Australian family, this means an extra $70-80 a week.
We'll also overcome the family debt crisis which has harmed 1.4 million Australian families.
We'll end the nightmare of having to haggle with Centrelink about undeserved debts to the government.
And a Labor Government will introduce income splitting for the benefit of single income couples - two tax free thresholds to help families where one partner stays at home.
For 30 years Mr Howard has been talking about income splitting.
But now, only Labor will deliver.
For the disadvantaged, our plan offers new opportunities in life.
We need to confront the problem of 800,000 Australian children growing up in jobless households.
We know what this leads to: poverty, poor health, increased crime rates and, worst of all, lack of hope.
This is the national shame we face as citizens under the Howard Government.
There are three answers to this problem: participation, participation and more participation.
By offering incentive and services, we can bring more people into the labour market,
and give our young people the best example they need in life - parents who work.
So if you want to know what our tax policy means in one line, it's this: fairness,
aspiration
and participation.
A fairer go for Australian families.
